item.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by voice vote. (text: CR 8/2/2007 H9503)
Passed/agreed to in House: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by voice vote.(text: CR 8/2/2007 H9503)
The previous question was ordered without objection. (consideration: CR 8/2/2007 H9507)
DEBATE - The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 597.
Considered as privileged matter. (consideration: CR 8/2/2007 H9503-9507)
Placed on the House Calendar, Calendar No. 99.
Rule provides for consideration of the conference report to H.R. 1495 with 1 hour of general debate.
The House Committee on Rules reported an original measure, H. Rept. 110-288, by Ms. Matsui.
The House Committee on Rules reported an original measure, H. Rept. 110-288, by Ms. Matsui.

summary.text: Sets forth the rule for consideration of the conference report to accompany the bill (H.R. 1495) to provide for the conservation and development of water and related resources, to authorize the Secretary of the Army to construct various projects for improvements to rivers and harbors of the United States.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.)

Waives points of order against consideration of the conference report on H.R. 1495 (Water Resources Development Act of 2007).

bill.title: Providing for consideration of the conference report to accompany the bill (H.R. 1495) to provide for the conservation and development of water and related resources, to authorize the Secretary of the Army to construct various projects for improvements to rivers and harbors of the United States, and for other purposes.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
